dt: {bc}a usually short fictitious story that illustrates a moral attitude or a religious principle

dt.t: the Biblical {wi}parable{/wi} of the Good Samaritan

dt: {bc}something (such as a news story or a series of real events) likened to a parable in providing an instructive example or lesson

dt.t: In some ways, his life is a {wi}parable{/wi} of the corrupting effect of great wealth, for he always assumed that everyone was after his money and out to cheat him.

By the summer of 2014, 380 House members and 74 senators had signed on as sponsors …. The ABLE Act had become a force. Yet in a {wi}parable{/wi} of how Washington works, the bill still had a long way to go.

et: Middle English {it}parable, parabol{/it} "allegorical narrative, proverb, speech," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}parable,{/it} going back to Late Latin {it}parabola{/it} "comparison, allegory, proverb, discourse, speech," going back to Latin, "explanatory illustration, comparison," borrowed from Greek {it}parabolḗ{/it} "juxtaposition, comparison," "proverb" (Septuagint), "parable" (New Testament), from {it}parabol-,{/it} stem in noun derivation of {it}parabállein{/it} "to cast before (as fodder for a horse), expose, set beside, compare," from {it}para-{/it} {et_link|para-:1|para-:1} + {it}bállein{/it} "to reach by throwing, let fly, strike, put, place" {ma}{mat|devil:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: a usually short fictitious story that illustrates a moral attitude or a religious principle; also : something (such as a news story or a series of real events) likened to a parable in providing an instructive example or lesson
